front.title: WIMSE Headless JWT Authentication and Authorization

abstract.t: In workload-to-service communication, a common pattern is for a workload to present a JSON Web Token (JWT) to a remote endpoint in order to obtain a temporary credential for the service it ultimately needs to access. It is a partial adaptation for workloads of existing flows designed for users. Implementing this pattern combines multiple existing standards from different working groups and standards bodies. Since this pattern is not described in a specification, it leads to variability in interoperability. The purpose of this document is to capture this common workload identity practice as an RFC in order to obtain consistency and promote interoperability in industry.
